advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #7</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A genius at your reach..."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR TECHNOLOGIES CREATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The conbination of Victor Business Products and Sirius Systems Technology Inc. creates a new company designed to meet the most demanding needs of the modern business office...<br> ... The result is Victor Technologies Inc., a company idally suited to dramatically impact today's international computer marketplace.<br><br> The Chairman of the board of the new Victor Technologies in Fred Sullivan, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Kiddle, Inc., a diversified $3 billion company. The financial support of this giant conglomerate will help focus Victor's goal of becoming one of the three leading computer companies in the world.<br> President and Chief Executive Officer of the new company is Chuck Peddle. Acknowledged as the "father" of the personal computer concept, Peddle introduced this useful and very affordable third generation micro-computer in the European market with startling results..</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #3 (1979) </strong></font><br><blockquote>From Playboy December 1979. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Peathead</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Arcades games in an armchair"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JUNE 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1986, the Alphatronic PC was bargained in many broker shops for a low price.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8086 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1982, Seattle Computer provided the 8086 version of the Gazelle with a free set of software: Microsoft MS-DOS, GW-Basic and the Perfect Writer word processor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the computing answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Japanese selling price was of 58.000 yen.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice computer, you place the level where you want"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH POSTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Poster in a 1982 english computer show.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Once upon a time, the future"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">PC Leaflets Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Galeb (English = Seagull) was an 8-bit computer developed by PEL Vara?din. It was largely inspired by the Compukit UK 101, Ohio Scientific Superboard and Superboard II computers that appeared in the U.K. and U.S.A. in 1979.
A grand total of 250 were produced by the end of the summer of 1984, before being replaced by Orao. (source Wikipedia)
Robert Kovac sent us this information about the Galeb (seagull) which was made by PEL Varazdin Co. and distributed by Velebit: I don't know the start of production, but PEL Varazdin ended with production at the end of 1984 and there were only 250 units produced (so it is extremely rare). It was replaced by the Orao (eagle), better and cheaper model.
The computer was designed by Miroslav Kocjan, who also designed the Orao. It was built around a MOS 6502 processor and had 16 KB ROM with a built-in monitor and a modified version of Microsoft BASIC, and 9 KB RAM (expandable to 64KB). In text mode it could display 16 rows with 48 columns and, in graphic mode 48 lines with 96 pixels each (both modes only in monochrome). It had a built-in speaker which could produce 1 voice with 5 octaves.
Thanks also to Robert for the pictures.
computer.name: Galeb
computer.ports: Composite video output, TV RF video output, Serial RS-232 port, Tape interface, Expansion connector

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> VELEBIT GALEB</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.foing.hr/~fng_josip/" target="_blank">Osobne stranice & Josip Perušanec</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.foing.hr/~fng_josip/" target="_blank">Osobne stranice & Josip Perušanec</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
